Problem:
Consider the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\) on a rod extending from \\(x=0\\) to \\(x=L\\), where \\(u\\) represents the temperature at point \\(x\\) at time \\(t\\), and \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We investigate the effects of an initial temperature distribution \\(u(x, 0) = f(x)\\) and its modification via a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}[f](k) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(x)e^{-ikx}dx\\).

Can we reconstruct the original temperature profile \\( f(x) \\) at \\( t = 0 \\) perfectly from observing \\(u(x, T)\\) at \\(t = T\\) if the Fourier transform was applied before the heat equation took effect?
Explanation: Even with knowledge of the Fourier transformation and the solution to the heat equation, diffusive processes are inherently lossy with respect to information about the high-frequency components of the initial profile. This information loss prevents exact reconstruction of \\( f(x) \\) from \\( u(x, T) \\).
